Fig 9 Research on structure-activity relationship dominated by template agents for mesoporous FeTi catalysts in SCR of NO with NH3 Yulin Li Resources Methodology Investigation a Zhiying liu Investigation Formal analysis a Xiao Li Validation Data curation Writing - original draft c ⁎ Yaqin Hou Conceptualization Supervision Writing - review & editing b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264005, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Yantai University Yantai 264005 China aSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264005, China b State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 China bState Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, China c School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Ludong University, Yantai 264025, China School of Chemistry and Materials Science Ludong University Yantai 264025 China cSchool of Chemistry and Materials Science, Ludong University, Yantai 264025, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. To gain more insight into the effect of the template used for preparing FeTi catalysts for the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitrogen oxide (NOx) on the catalytic structure and performance, a systematic study on FeTi catalysts synthesized using F127, CTAB, and PEG as templates is described. The catalysts exhibited outstanding performance in the SCR of NOx with NH3, exceeding that of a pure FeTi catalyst. Especially, the CTAB-modified FeTi catalyst achieved 100% of NOx conversion at 200 °C. A thorough morphological characterization showed that, compared with F127 and PEG, CTAB induced the formation of smaller catalyst particles with larger surface area, which could provide more acid sites and facilitate the adsorption of NH3, thus contributing to the enhanced activity. In addition, in-situ DRIFTS revealed that the reaction followed the Langmuir–Hinshelwood and Eley–Rideal mechanism, with the coordination of NH3 on Lewis acid sites and the bridged nitrate playing key roles in improving the catalytic performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Template NH3-SCR NOx FeTi 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NOx) is one of the main pollutants causing acid rain, the ozone hole and surface water eutrophication. In addition, it seriously damages the ecological environment and human health, there it is the focus of attention in current environmental protection research [1–3]. In this context, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) is widely used as a flue gas denitrification(deNOx) technology at present. The most common commercial deNOx catalyst used for this purpose is V2O5-WO3/TiO2, whose working temperature is 330–400 °C [4,5]. In the SCR process, the reactor must be placed before a dedusting and desulfurization system. High dust and its poisons (alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, heavy metals, SO2) can easily lead to poisoning and deactivation of the catalyst [6]. However, the flue gas temperature is usually low if the catalyst is placed after the dedusting and desulfurization system, Therefore, the development of low temperature (< 280 °C) SCR catalysts has attracted increasing research attention. Among the wide variety of catalysts tested, those based on Fe species are considered to be the most promising ones due to their low cost, variable valence states and high chemical stability. Especially the iron titanium catalysts have been widely studied in recent years. Kato et al. [7] used the impregnation method to prepare an Fe/TiO2 catalyst with good SCR activity at temperatures below 300 °C. Liu et al. [8,9] reported that iron titanium catalysts synthesized by coprecipitation method showed excellent performance with an NOx conversion of over 80% at 250 °C. The high dispersion of iron and titanium species in atomic scale was the key factor to improve the activity. Additionally, the sol-gel method has been applied to prepare FeTi catalysts with large specific surface area and mesoporous volume, which were beneficial to catalytic performance [10]. However, the catalysts prepared by the abovementioned methods, do not provide satisfactory operation-temperature window and SCR activity at low-temperature. Recently, an in-situ approach via a template-assisted process has emerged as a promising method to prepare porous materials. A series of organic molecules; such as pluronic F127, and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), has been used as templates to optimize the catalyst structure for a high catalytic performance. Lv et al. [11] found that ZnFe2O4 catalyst prepared using CTAB as a template exhibited nanorod-shape morphologies, thus showing good photostability in an aqueous suspension. Ahmad et al. [12] reported the preparation of PtIrNi catalyst via an F127-assisted process, affording an improved catalytic activity toward ethanol oxidation. Meanwhile, Wang et al. [13] described a CuO catalyst with excellent catalytic performance in the degradation of phenolic organic pollutants. This catalyst was prepared using polyethylene glycol (PEG) as a template. Although the template-assisted synthesis has already been proved to be an effective method for catalyst preparation. To the best of our knowledge, no comparative study on the effect of using different templates for the preparation of FeTi catalysts for the SCR reaction has been reported to date. The present study aims to fill this gap of knowledge by focusing on the following aspects: (i) the effects of different templates on the physicochemical properties of the synthesized FeTi catalysts; (ii) the relationship between the catalyst structure and the SCR performance depending on the template; and (iii) the intrinsic mechanism of the template-governed SCR reaction. To achieve this goal, FeTi catalysts were synthesized using F127, CTAB, and PEG as templates, respectively, and applied to the SCR of NOx with NH3. The influence of the templates on the structure and activity of the obtained FeTi catalysts was studied systematically to provide a template-governed strategy for the preparation of highly active SCR catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All the chemical reagents used were of analytical grade. Typically, 2.0 g of F127 was dissolved in 50 mL of absolute ethanol at room temperature. Subsequently, tetrabutyltitanate (34 mL) and CH3COOH (9 mL) were added into the above solution, and the mixture was stirred until the solution was clear. Then, a solution containing 5.8 g of Fe(NO3)3•9H2O in 9 mL of deionized water was added dropwise. After stirring for 2 h, the resultant product was aged at room temperature for 3 days to yield a transparent gel. To remove the template completely, the gel was dried at 110 °C overnight and calcined at 450 °C in air for 3 h at a heating rate of 2 °C/min. The obtained catalyst was named FeTi(f). Similarly, FeTi(c) and FeTi(p) were also synthesized using CTAB (1.5 g) and PEG (2.0 g) were used as the template, respectively, following the procedure described above. In addition, for comparison, a sample without template (named as FeTi) was prepared by the same method. 2.2. Catalyst characterization The textural structures of the samples were measured by N2-adsorption at -196 °C in a Micromeritics ASAP2020 instrument. The specific surface area was determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, and the pore size distributions were calculated by BJH method. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on an X-ray diffractometer (D8 ADVANCE), operating at 40 kV and 45 mA with a step of 2° ranging from 10 to 90°. The morphology of the catalyst was observed by a scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-7001F, JEOL, Japan). TPD and TPR experiments were conducted on a ChemStar chemisorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instrument Crop) under a total flow rate of 50 mL/min. Before experiment, 0.5 g of catalyst was pretreated in pure N2 at 300 °C for 1 h. The outlet concentration was continuously monitored by a TCD detector. In-situ Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) was collected from 4000 to 1000 cm−1 by a Bruker Tensor 27 instrument equipped with a MCT detector. The spectra was obtained at the resolution of 8 cm−1 with 100 scans in Kubelka-Munk mode. 2.3 NH3-SCR activity test 1 shut-off valve; 2 mass flow controller; 3 mixing chamber; 4 rotameter; 5 catalyst; 6 reactor; 7 furnace; 8 program temperature controller; 9 flue gas analyzer The schematic diagram of experimental apparatus for SCR measurement is displayed in Fig. 1 . The test was carried out on a fixed-bed reactor (length 250 mm, internal diameter 12 mm) under a simulated flue gas containing 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 6.5 vol.% O2, N2 balance. The total gas flow rate was maintained at 400 mL/ min over 2.0 g of the catalyst, corresponding to a GHSV of 12000 h−1. The NOx concentration at the inlet and outlet were analyzed by a flue gas analyzer (KM9106 Quintox, Kane International Limited). NOx conversion = ( 1 − [ N O x ] out [ N O x ] in ) × 100 % with [ N O x ] = [ NO ] [ + N O 2 ] N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = ( [ N O x ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − 2 [ N 2 O ] out − [ N O x ] out − [ N H 3 ] out [ N O x ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − [ N O x ] out − [ N H 3 ] out ) × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR activity As shown in Fig. 2 , the NOx conversion and N2 selectivity over the catalysts were evaluated for the NH3-SCR reaction between 90 °C and 360 °C. It could be seen from Fig. 2(a) that FeTi exhibited the lowest NOx conversion, and only less than 50% of NOx was removed below 240 °C. In contrast, the template-modified catalysts displayed high NOx removal efficiency and wide large operation temperature window. The catalytic activity followed the order: FeTi(c)>FeTi(f)>FeTi(p). FeTi(c) exhibited the best performance with approximately 100% of NOx conversion at 210 °C, whereas the same value was obtained with FeTi(f) and FeTi(p) at 240 °C and 270 °C, respectively. Fig. 2(b) shows that all the catalysts exhibited a high N2 selectivity; of nearly 100%. However, it is worth noting that the N2 selectivity presented an obvious decrease due to the competitive reaction of NH3 oxidation by O2 at temperatures higher than 300 °C, thus resulting in a decrease in NOx conversion. It is widely accepted that the template, as a structural and chemical promoter, can optimize the catalyst structure and improve the catalytic performance [14]. According to the above results, CTAB served as a better template promoting the SCR performance compared with F127 and PEG. 3.2 Textural characteristics Table 1. Physical property of catalysts. Table 1 Samples SBET (m2•g−1) Pore volume(cm3•g−1) Average pore diameter(nm) FeTi 91.34 0.31 23.32 FeTi(c) 128.30 0.21 2.82 FeTi(f) 115.12 0.19 6.21 FeTi(p) 107.78 0.15 9.82 To compare the structure properties of the different catalysts, the specific area, pore volume, and the average pore diameter of the catalysts were determined, and the results are summarized in Table 1. The pore size distributions are plotted in Fig. 3 . FeTi catalyst presented a wide pore distribution ranging from 15 to 30 nm, a small specific surface area of 91 m2•g−1 and a large pore volume of 0.31 cm3•g−1. An obvious decrease of the pore diameter was noticed with the introduction of the templates. Meanwhile, uniform mesopores were formed due to the structure-directing effect of the templates, which weakened the interfacial energy and capillary stress in the pores, causing a decrease in the surface tension during the calcination process [15,16]. Once the template was removed, various types of pores were formed at the void spaces. According to the data of Table 1, the pore diameter of the catalysts followed the order: FeTi(c)< FeTi(f)< FeTi(p), whereas the specific surface area and pore volume showed the reverse change trend. The results indicated that particles with a smaller pore diameter were formed under the structure directing effect of CTAB. This led to an increase of the specific surface area and the pore volume, which not only facilitated the transportations of reactants, but also promoted the dispersion of active composition, thereby contributing to the high catalytic performance. In addition, the normalized catalytic reaction rate by the surface area is shown in Fig. S1. The NOx conversion after normalization gradually decreased following the sequence: FeTi(c)>FeTi(f)> FeTi(p)> FeTi, indicating that the surface area was not the main reason for the increased NOx conversion, other factors such as the changed active species, the reducibility of the catalyst, and the surface acid sites under the influence of the template should be also considered. 3.3 Structural and morphology analysis (XRD and SEM) XRD patterns of the catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4 . The characteristic diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS 21–1272) were observed at 25°, 38°, 48°, 54° and 62° to for all the samples. It should be noted that the diffraction peaks became broad after template modification. The primary crystallite size was estimated by the Scherrer equation to be 25, 18, 16 and 12 nm, for FeTi, FeTi(p), FeTi(f) and FeTi(c) respectively, suggesting that the use of template agent led to smaller catalyst particles. In addition, several weak peaks appeared at 33° and 41°, in accordance with Fe2O3. Interestingly, the Fe2O3 characteristic peaks for FeTi catalyst almost vanished, implying that Fe2O3 might exist in an amorphous structure. The diffraction peak intensity of Fe2O3 was stronger for the template-modified catalysts than for the pure FeTi catalyst, which is indicative of the change in the crystalline structure under the influence of the template, in accordance with our previous study [17]. To gain insight into the influence of the templates on the catalyst morphology, SEM characterization was conducted and representative images are shown in Fig. 5 . Large particles were observed on the surface of FeTi, which might affect considerably the specific surface area and the dispersion of active composition. In contrast, the particles became smaller and no agglomeration was detected on the surface of the template-modified catalyst. Generally, during the synthesis process, the template was mixed with the catalyst precursor and formed a subject-object compound by self-assembly of organic and inorganic molecules. When the template was consumed, the specific mesoporous structure was built [16,18]. Different templates resulted in diverse mesoporous structures, which affected the catalyst morphology. According to the above results, it can be deduced that CTAB template induced the formation of smaller mesoporous structures and fine particles, which had a positive impact on the catalytic activity. 3.4 NH3-TPD analysis Surface acidity is believed to play a key role in the SCR reaction [19], therefore an NH3-TPD experiment was performed to investigated the effect of the templates on the surface acidity of the catalysts. The corresponding desorption curves of the samples are illustrated in Fig. 6 (a), which exhibits three desorption peaks for each catalyst. One weak desorption peak at 120 °C can be attributed to the desorption of physiosorbed NH3 and some NH4 + ascribed to weak Brønsted acid sites [20]. The broad peak spanned in the temperature range of 220–360 °C was assigned to the NH3 species desorbed from weak and medium acid sites, and the peak appearing at 450 °C corresponded to the NH3 species desorbed from strong acid sites [21]. The NH3 adsorption capacity was estimated by integrating the desorption curves (Fig. 6(b)) and the results showed that adsorption capacity changed as the following sequence: FeTi(c) (0.23 mmol•g−1)>FeTi(f) (0.22 mmol•g−1)>FeTi(c) (0.17 mmol•g−1)>FeTi (0.08 mmol•g−1), revealing that the introduction of the templates increased the number of catalyst acid sites and promoted the NH3 adsorption. This might be related to the optimized specific surface area and pore structure. Besides, CTAB acted as a cationic surfactant molecule releasing CTA+, which can interact with negatively charged sites on the catalyst surface during the dry and calcination process, affecting the distribution of the acid sites [22]. It is noteworthy that a larger number of strong acid sites was found on FeTi(f), whereas FeTi(c) had more weak-medium acid sites. According to the literature, NH3 acid sites are determining factors affecting the SCR reaction path, i.e., Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) or Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanisms. Therefore, it can be concluded that the template modification not only affected the amount of acid sites but also changed the type of acid sites, thus leading to diverse reaction behavior. 3.5 TPR analysis The reducibility of the catalysts was investigated by H2-TPR, and the results are depicted in Fig. 7 . For all the samples, a broad peak spanned in the range of 200–550 °C could be observed, which can be ascribed to the consecutive reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 and, subsequently, to Fe [23,24]. The Fe reduction peak for FeTi appeared at 412 °C, however, this peak shifted to lower temperature for the template-modified catalysts, and the order of reduction temperature was FeTi(c)< FeTi(f)=FeTi(p)<FeTi. This phenomenon indicated that the reducibility of catalysts was enhanced in the influence of template, facilitating the reaction of hydrogen with oxygen atoms of the catalyst surface. The activation of adsorbed NH3 molecules on the catalyst surface, which is directly related to the catalyst reducibility, has been proposed as a major step for SCR reaction [25]. Accordingly, FeTi(c) exhibited the lowest reduction temperature, which is in agreement with the high NOx conversion. 3.6 In-situ DRIFTS To further study the influence of the templates on the species adsorbed on the catalyst surface, in-situ DRIFTS was employed to characterize the adsorption of NH3 and NO+O2 at 200°C. As illustrated in Fig. 8 (a), after the catalyst exposing the catalysts to a 1000 ppm NH3/N2 steam for 30 min, several bands at 1187, 1437, 1535, 1602 cm−1 and a broad band at 3000–3500 cm−1 were detected. The bands at 1187 and 1602 cm−1 can be attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of NH3 on Lewis acidic sites, respectively [14,26], while the one located at 1437 cm−1 is assigned to NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites. The band at 1535 cm−1 suggested the presence of amide species (-NH2) owing to partial oxidation by active composition [27]. The broad band ranging from 3000 to 3500 cm−1 belonged to the N-H stretching vibration of NH3 or NH4 + species [28]. It was evident that the peak intensity of Lewis acid sites (1187 and 1602 cm−1) were remarkably increased for the template-modified catalysts, especially for FeTi(c), which showed stronger peaks than FeTi(f) and FeTi(p), suggesting that the physicochemical properties with the CTAB modification were favorable for the formation of Lewis acid sites. In addition, the adsorbed NH3 on the surface of FeTi(c) was thermally more stable than that of the other catalysts, which still maintained a relatively higher peak intensity at 300°C (Fig. S2 in the Supplementary material). According to the reaction mechanisms (E-R or/and L-H mechanism), NH3 would be first absorbed on the Lewis or Brønsted acidic sites and then oxidized by active composition to generate -NH2, which would react with gaseous or adsorbed NO species. As a consequence, the more NH3 the catalyst adsorbs, the more NO the reaction consumes, which is consistent with the results of the activity measurements. Co-adsorption of NO+O2 on the catalyst surface was investigated by in-situ DRIFTS, and the corresponding spectra are illustrated in Fig. 8(b). Four bands at 1240, 1276, 1574 and 1612 cm−1 were detected after the adsorption of 1000 ppm NO + 6.5 vol.% O2 and N2 purging. The bands located at 1240 and 1612 cm−1 belonged to bridged nitrate, and that at 1276 cm−1 can be attributed to the unstable monodentate nitrate [24,29,30]. The band at 1574 cm−1 can be assigned to the bidentate nitrate [27]. It is worth noting that the signal intensities of bidentate nitrate (1574 cm−1) and bridged nitrate (1612 cm−1) for FeTi were very weak and therefore negligible; however, they were significantly enhanced after the template modification, especially for the FeTi(c) catalyst. Moreover, the NO adsorbed on the surface of FeTi(c) and FeTi(f) showed higher thermal stability than that of the other two catalysts (Fig. S3 in the Supplementary material). These results implied that the properties of the template-modified catalysts were conductive to the adsorption of NO species, and thus improved catalytic performance according to the L-H mechanism [31]. To determine the reaction behaviors of the adsorbed species on the catalyst surface, in-situ DRIFTS of reaction was conducted for the reaction at 200°C using FeTi(c) as an example. FeTi(c) was first treated with 1000 ppm NH3/N2 for 30 min, followed by N2 purging, and then NO+O2/N2 was introduced into the reaction cell. The spectra were recorded as a function of time (Fig. 9 (a)). As discussed above, NH4 + species (1437 cm−1), NH3 species (1187 cm−1 and 1602 cm−1), and -NH2 species (1525 cm−1) appeared on the catalyst surface. Upon introducing NO+O2 introduction, the band at 1437 cm−1 ascribed to the Brønsted acid sites decreased quickly until it was undetectable within the first 10 min. In contrast, the NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites was consumed slowly with increasing reaction time, and nearly vanished after 30 min. This suggests that Lewis acid sites might play a more prominent role in improving the catalytic performance. In addition, the band at 1535 cm−1 attributed to the intermediate of NH3 oxidation decreased gradually, which agrees with previously reported results [30]. Furthermore, the experiment was repeated by introducing the reactants in the reversed order. FeTi(c) was first treated with 1000 ppm NO+O2/N2 for 30 min, followed by N2 purging. Then, NH3/N2 was introduced into the reaction cell, and the spectra were recorded. As shown in Fig. 9(b), bridged nitrate (1240 and 1612 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1276 cm−1), and bidentate nitrate (1574 cm−1) were detected after NO+O2 adsorption. Once NH3 was introduced, the band ascribed to bridged nitrate showed a continuous decline, whereas those of monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate increased slightly. The phenomenon revealed that bridged nitrate reacted directly with NH3, and bridged nitrate might transform to the monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate because of the interaction between NH3 and adsorbed NO species. The bands of bridged nitrate nearly disappeared within 30 min. These results, together with those of the reaction mechanism, suggest that the removal of NO proceeded not only via the E-R path but also L-H path. 4 Conclusions In summary, the effect of CTAB, F127 and PEG as templates on the physicochemical properties and SCR performance of FeTi catalysts was studied. It was found that the SCR performance of the template-modified catalysts was much better than that of the pure FeTi catalyst, especially for FeTi(c), which showed an NOx conversion efficiency of 100% at 200 °C. FeTi(c) exhibited smaller particles and larger surface area than FeTi(f) and FeTi(p), which was beneficial to the NH3 adsorption, as confirmed by the NH3-TPD analysis. In addition, in-situ DRIFTS revealed that the reaction followed the E-R and L-H mechanisms, and the catalytic performance was greatly affected by the strength of coordinated NH3 on the Lewis acids sites and bridged nitrate. coredata.dc:description: To gain more insight into the effect of the template used for preparing FeTi catalysts for the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitrogen oxide (NOx) on the catalytic structure and performance, a systematic study on FeTi catalysts synthesized using F127, CTAB, and PEG as templates is described. The catalysts exhibited outstanding performance in the SCR of NOx with NH3, exceeding that of a pure FeTi catalyst. Especially, the CTAB-modified FeTi catalyst achieved 100% of NOx conversion at 200 °C. A thorough morphological characterization showed that, compared with F127 and PEG, CTAB induced the formation of smaller catalyst particles with larger surface area, which could provide more acid sites and facilitate the adsorption of NH3, thus contributing to the enhanced activity. In addition, in-situ DRIFTS revealed that the reaction followed the Langmuir–Hinshelwood and Eley–Rideal mechanism, with the coordination of NH3 on Lewis acid sites and the bridged nitrate playing key roles in improving the catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Research on structure-activity relationship dominated by template agents for mesoporous FeTi catalysts in SCR of NO with NH3
